question.title: Will Mike Pence be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Mike Pence is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently below; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Mike Pence becoming the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current political landscape: As of now, Donald Trump is the front-runner for the Republican nomination, with other candidates like Ron DeSantis, Nikki Haley, and Tim Scott also in the race. Mike Pence has not officially announced his candidacy yet. 2. Pence's relationship with Trump: As Trump's former Vice President, Pence had a falling out with Trump over the 2020 election results and the events of January 6th. This has likely damaged his standing with Trump's base, which is a significant portion of the Republican electorate. 3. Pence's appeal: While Pence has strong conservative credentials and experience as Vice President, he lacks the charisma and populist appeal that have driven recent Republican primaries. 4. Polling data: Current polls show Pence trailing significantly behind other potential candidates, often polling in single digits. 5. Fundraising: Pence's fundraising efforts have been modest compared to other potential candidates, which could limit his ability to run an effective campaign. 6. Time until the convention: There is still considerable time until the Republican National Convention in 2024, which means the political landscape could change. However, Pence would need to overcome significant obstacles to become a frontrunner. 7. Historical precedent: It's rare for a former Vice President to win their party's nomination without having been President, especially when competing against their former running mate. Given these factors, it seems highly unlikely that Mike Pence will be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. While it's not impossible, the odds are stacked against him. He would need a dramatic shift in the political landscape, a significant change in voter preferences, and a strong campaign performance to overcome the current frontrunners.

question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if both of the following occur: (a) Ted Cruz is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, and (b) Mike Pence is not selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. The field is currently dominated by figures like Donald Trump and Ron DeSantis. 2. Ted Cruz's position: Cruz ran for the nomination in 2016 and came second to Trump. He has maintained a high profile in the Senate but hasn't indicated a strong intention to run in 2024. His chances of securing the nomination seem low at this point. 3. Mike Pence's position: As a former Vice President, Pence has some name recognition, but his relationship with Trump has soured since the 2020 election aftermath. He has shown interest in running but hasn't gained significant traction in early polls. 4. Historical precedent: It's rare for a senator (like Cruz) to secure the nomination, and even rarer for someone who isn't currently seen as a top-tier candidate to emerge victorious. 5. Time until the convention: The Republican National Convention is still about a year away. While this allows time for the political landscape to change, it would require a significant shift for Cruz to become the nominee. 6. The specific nature of the question: For this to resolve as 'Yes,' we need both Cruz to win AND Pence not to win. While the latter is more likely, the former is highly improbable based on current information. Given these factors, the probability of this specific scenario occurring is very low. Cruz securing the nomination is already unlikely, and while it's more probable that Pence won't be the nominee, the combination of both events makes this scenario highly improbable.

question.body:

Resolves the same as the original on Metaculus.

(https://www.metaculus.com/questions/question_embed/25755/?theme=dark)Resolution criteria

This question will resolve as Yes if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle.

To qualify for a Yes resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle.

If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as No.

Fine print and additional background information can be found on Metaculus.

question.title: Will the USA win more Gold than Silver medals at the Paris 2024 Olympics?

Given these factors, it's more likely than not that the USA will win more gold medals than silver medals in Paris 2024. question.body:
This question will resolve positively if both of the following occur:
(a) The United States Olympic Team are the (unique) highest ranked team at the 2024 Paris Olympics. The medal table is calculated by taking all the medals won by each participating country and ordering by:
1. Number of Gold Medals
2. (Where 1 is tied) Number of Silver Medals
3. (Where 2 is tied) Number of Bronze Medals

(b) The United States Olympic Team wins as many or more Silver medals than Gold medals at the Paris 2024 Olympics.

The question will resolve ambiguously if the Paris Olympics do not take place before 2027.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, we need to consider two separate components and their likelihood of occurring simultaneously. 1. USA topping the Olympic Medal Table: The United States has consistently been a top performer at the Summer Olympics. In recent history, they have topped the medal table in terms of total medals and gold medals in 2016 (Rio) and 2020 (Tokyo). Their strong performance across a wide range of sports gives them a high probability of topping the medal table again in Paris 2024. 2. USA winning as many or more Silver than Gold medals: This is a more unusual occurrence. Typically, top-performing countries tend to win more gold medals than silver. Looking at recent Olympics: - In Tokyo 2020, USA won 39 gold and 41 silver - In Rio 2016, USA won 46 gold and 37 silver - In London 2012, USA won 46 gold and 29 silver While it's not impossible for a country to win more silver than gold medals, it's less common for the top-performing country. The Tokyo 2020 results show it can happen, but it's not the norm. Combining these factors: The USA has a high chance of topping the medal table, but a lower chance of winning as many or more silver than gold medals. For both to occur simultaneously, we need to multiply these probabilities, which will result in a lower overall probability. Given the USA's consistent performance and the precedent set in Tokyo 2020, I would estimate there's about a 60% chance of the USA topping the medal table, and perhaps a 40% chance of them winning as many or more silver than gold medals. The combined probability would be approximately 0.60 * 0.40 = 0.24 or 24%.

question.title: Will either of the following occur at the Paris 2024 Olympics: (a) The USA wins more Gold than Silver medals (b) The USA tops the Olympic Medal Table?
question.body:
This question resolves YES if either of the following conditions are met:
(a) The United States Olympic Team wins more Gold medals than Silver medals at the Paris 2024 Olympics.
(b) The United States Olympic Team is the unique highest ranked team at the 2024 Paris Olympics, based on the medal table which orders countries by the number of Gold medals, then Silver medals, then Bronze medals. This question resolves ambiguously if the Paris Olympics do not take place before 2027. It resolves NO if neither condition is met.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, we need to consider historical Olympic performance of the United States and current trends in international sports. The United States has consistently been a top performer at the Olympics. In recent Summer Olympics: - Tokyo 2020 (held in 2021): USA topped the medal table with 39 gold, 41 silver, and 33 bronze. - Rio 2016: USA topped the medal table with 46 gold, 37 silver, and 38 bronze. - London 2012: USA topped the medal table with 46 gold, 29 silver, and 29 bronze. In Tokyo 2020, the US won slightly fewer gold than silver medals, but in Rio 2016 and London 2012, they won more gold than silver. This shows that winning more gold than silver is certainly possible and has happened in recent Olympics. The US has consistently topped the medal table in recent Summer Olympics. Their main competitors are typically China and occasionally Russia (competing as ROC or under other designations due to doping sanctions). The US continues to have strong programs in swimming, athletics, gymnastics, and team sports, which contribute significantly to their medal count. However, other nations are constantly improving their Olympic programs, potentially narrowing the gap. Given that this question was created in 2021 and the Olympics are scheduled for 2024, there's a very high likelihood that the event will take place before 2027, so we don't need to factor in the ambiguous resolution significantly. Considering all these factors, there's a high probability that at least one of the conditions will be met. The US has a strong chance of topping the medal table based on recent performance, and even if they don't, they have a good chance of winning more gold than silver medals.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024:

Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.

The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution.

The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

metadata.chain_of_thought: This is a complex question that requires careful consideration of several factors: 1. Legal precedent: There have been attempts to use Section 3 of the 14th Amendment to disqualify candidates in the past, but they have rarely been successful. However, the events of January 6, 2021, and Trump's alleged role in them have created a unique situation. 2. Current legal challenges: As of now, there are ongoing efforts in several states to remove Trump from the ballot using this argument. Colorado and Maine have already made decisions to remove Trump from their primary ballots, though these decisions are being appealed. 3. Supreme Court involvement: The U.S. Supreme Court has agreed to hear the Colorado case, which could set a nationwide precedent. Their decision will likely have a significant impact on similar efforts in other states. 4. Timing: The resolution date is July 15, 2024, which is after most primary elections will have taken place. This gives ample time for legal challenges to be resolved. 5. Political climate: The issue is highly contentious and politically charged, which could influence decision-making processes in different states. 6. State-by-state variation: Different states may interpret and apply the 14th Amendment differently, potentially leading to varied outcomes across the country. Given these factors, I believe there is a significant chance that Trump will be removed or blocked from at least one state's primary ballot by the resolution date. The Colorado and Maine decisions, even if overturned, demonstrate that some states are willing to take this step. The Supreme Court's decision will be crucial, but even if it rules in Trump's favor, there's a possibility that at least one state might still find grounds to remove him from their ballot. However, the high-profile nature of the case and the potential for the Supreme Court to set a clear precedent that would apply nationwide somewhat reduces the likelihood of this outcome.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (1) Donald Trump will be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, and (2) Donald Trump will not be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if both of the following conditions are met:

1. Donald Trump is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. This is determined by who is selected by the delegates of the Republican National Convention, regardless of who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election.

2. As of July 15, 2024, Donald Trump has not been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment. There must be no official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports confirming such a removal or block. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution. The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur after the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has not been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves positively.

The question will resolve as **No** if either or both of these conditions are not met.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, we need to consider both conditions separately and then combine our assessments. 1. Donald Trump becoming the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election: Trump remains a dominant figure in the Republican Party and has a strong base of supporters. He has already announced his candidacy and is leading in many polls for the Republican primary. However, he faces several challenges: - Legal issues, including multiple indictments - Competition from other Republican candidates like Ron DeSantis - Potential fatigue among some Republican voters Despite these challenges, Trump's influence on the party and his dedicated base make him a frontrunner. I would estimate the probability of him becoming the nominee at around 70%. 2. Trump not being removed or blocked from any state's primary ballot under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment: This is a more complex issue. Several attempts have been made to use the 14th Amendment to disqualify Trump from running, based on his alleged role in the January 6th Capitol riot. However: - Most legal experts believe such attempts face significant hurdles - The Supreme Court has not ruled on this issue, creating uncertainty - Many Republican-controlled states are unlikely to attempt such a move - Even if attempted, legal challenges could reverse such decisions before July 15, 2024 Given these factors, I would estimate the probability of Trump not being removed or blocked from any state's ballot under these grounds at about 85%. To resolve YES, both conditions must be met. We multiply the probabilities: 0.70 * 0.85 = 0.595 or 59.5%. This calculation assumes the events are independent, which may not be entirely accurate as legal challenges could affect both outcomes. However, it provides a reasonable estimate.

question.title: Will either of the following occur: (a) Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment by July 15, 2024? (b) Donald Trump be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if either of the following conditions is met:

(a) As of July 15, 2024, Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment. The removal or block must be confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution. The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur after the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

(b) Donald Trump is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as "No". This question may consider new candidates added in the future. It is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the Republican National Convention.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, we need to consider both conditions (a) and (b) separately, as the question will resolve as 'Yes' if either of these conditions is met. (a) Regarding Trump being removed or blocked from primary election ballots: There have been attempts to disqualify Trump from ballots using Section 3 of the 14th Amendment, citing his alleged role in the January 6th Capitol riot. Some states (e.g., Colorado, Maine) have already made moves to remove Trump from their primary ballots, although these decisions have faced legal challenges. The U.S. Supreme Court has agreed to hear arguments on this issue, which suggests it's a serious constitutional question. However, given the conservative majority on the Supreme Court and the unprecedented nature of such a disqualification, it seems unlikely that Trump will be permanently removed from ballots in multiple states by July 15, 2024. Even if some states do remove him, there's a high chance of legal battles and potential reinstatements before the specified date. (b) Regarding Trump being the Republican nominee: Trump is currently the front-runner for the Republican nomination, with a significant lead in most polls. He has a strong base of support within the Republican Party. Despite legal challenges and controversies, his popularity among Republican voters remains high. The Republican establishment, while sometimes at odds with Trump, has largely fallen in line behind him in previous elections. While there are other candidates in the race, none have shown the ability to seriously challenge Trump's position so far. Considering both conditions, it seems more likely than not that at least one of these conditions will be met, with Trump becoming the Republican nominee being the more probable outcome. The ballot removal scenario, while possible, faces significant legal and political hurdles.

question.title: Will Mike Pence be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Mike Pence is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently below; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Mike Pence becoming the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current political landscape: As of now, Donald Trump is still the frontrunner for the Republican nomination, with other candidates like Ron DeSantis and Nikki Haley also gaining traction. Mike Pence has not been polling as strongly as these candidates. 2. Pence's relationship with Trump: Pence's actions during the January 6th Capitol riot and its aftermath have strained his relationship with Trump and Trump's base. This could significantly hurt his chances of winning the nomination. 3. Pence's campaign: While Pence has launched his presidential campaign, it hasn't gained significant momentum. He's struggling to differentiate himself from other candidates and appeal to a broad Republican base. 4. Fundraising: Pence's fundraising efforts have been modest compared to top-tier candidates, which limits his ability to run a competitive national campaign. 5. Name recognition: While Pence has high name recognition as the former Vice President, this hasn't translated into strong support among Republican voters. 6. Republican party dynamics: The party seems to be leaning towards either Trump or a Trump-like figure, which doesn't align well with Pence's more traditional conservative approach. 7. Time until convention: There's still time for dynamics to change, but Pence would need a significant shift in voter sentiment to become a frontrunner. Given these factors, it seems highly unlikely that Mike Pence will be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. While it's not impossible - unexpected events could dramatically change the landscape - the current evidence suggests a very low probability.

question.title: Will Nikki Haley be the Republican nominee and Mike Pence not be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if both of the following occur: (a) Nikki Haley is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, and (b) Mike Pence is not selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of this scenario, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current political landscape: As of now, Donald Trump is the clear frontrunner for the Republican nomination, with Ron DeSantis as his main challenger. Nikki Haley and Mike Pence are both considered long-shot candidates. 2. Nikki Haley's chances: While Haley has some support and name recognition, she's currently polling far behind Trump and DeSantis. Her moderate stance might appeal to some Republicans, but it's not enough to make her a favorite. 3. Mike Pence's position: Pence's chances are even slimmer than Haley's. His association with the Trump administration and subsequent falling out with Trump have damaged his standing with both Trump supporters and Trump critics. 4. Potential for unexpected events: There's always a possibility of major political shifts or scandals that could dramatically change the race. However, these are unpredictable and relatively rare. 5. Historical precedent: It's unusual for a party to nominate someone who isn't either a clear frontrunner or a strong second-place candidate early in the race. 6. Time until the convention: There's still time for dynamics to change, but major shifts in candidate standings typically happen earlier in the primary process. Given these factors, the scenario where Nikki Haley becomes the nominee while Mike Pence does not is highly unlikely. For this to happen, not only would both Trump and DeSantis need to falter significantly, but Haley would need to surge past several other candidates, including Pence. While it's almost certain that Pence won't be the nominee, Haley's chances of securing the nomination are very low.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of either Mike Pence or Nikki Haley becoming the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, we need to consider several factors: 1. Mike Pence's position: While Pence has name recognition as the former Vice President, his relationship with Trump has soured since the events of January 6, 2021. Nikki Haley's position: Haley has already announced her candidacy and has some support as a more moderate alternative. However, she's currently polling well behind Trump and DeSantis. 4. Time until the convention: The Republican National Convention is still over a year away. Given these factors, while it's not impossible for either Pence or Haley to become the nominee, it seems unlikely at this point. question.title: Will Chris Christie be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Chris Christie becoming the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, we need to consider several factors: 1. Christie's position: Chris Christie has been a vocal critic of Donald Trump, which puts him at odds with a large portion of the Republican base that still strongly supports Trump. 3. Given these factors, especially Christie's current low polling numbers, his opposition to the party's current frontrunner, and the overall political climate within the Republican Party, the probability of Chris Christie becoming the Republican nominee is very low.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) A member of the Trump family is the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024 (b) Chris Christie is not the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question resolves **Yes** if both of the following conditions are met:

(a) A member of the Trump family is the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024. This includes any of the following individuals being the nominee:
 - Donald Trump
 - Donald Trump Jr.
 - Eric Trump
 - Ivanka Trump
 - Tiffany Trump
 - Melania Trump
 - Barron Trump

(b) Chris Christie is not selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. It does not matter who else is selected as the nominee, as long as it is not Chris Christie. This determination is based on the selection by the delegates of the Republican National Convention, not on the eventual candidate on the day of the election.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of both conditions occurring, we need to analyze each part separately and then combine them. (a) A member of the Trump family being the Republican nominee: Donald Trump is currently the frontrunner for the 2024 Republican nomination. He has a strong base of supporters within the party and has consistently led in polls. While he faces legal challenges and some opposition within the party, his influence remains significant. Other Trump family members have much lower chances of becoming the nominee. The probability of a Trump family member (most likely Donald Trump himself) being the nominee is high, around 70-80%. (b) Chris Christie not being the Republican nominee: Chris Christie has announced his candidacy for the 2024 Republican nomination. However, his chances of winning the nomination are relatively low. He has been polling in the low single digits and faces significant challenges: 1. He's positioning himself as an anti-Trump candidate in a party where Trump still holds considerable sway. 2. He lacks the national support base that some other candidates have. 3. His previous presidential run in 2016 was unsuccessful. 4. There are other candidates who appeal to similar voter demographics but with less baggage. The probability of Chris Christie not being the nominee is very high, around 95-98%. Combining these probabilities: For both conditions to occur, we need a Trump family member (likely Donald Trump) to win AND Chris Christie not to win. Since these events are not entirely independent (Christie's chances decrease if Trump's increase), we can't simply multiply the probabilities. However, given the high likelihood of Christie not winning regardless of who does win, the combined probability is primarily determined by the chances of a Trump family member winning. Considering all factors, I would estimate the probability of both conditions occurring to be slightly lower than the probability of a Trump family member winning alone, to account for the small chance that Christie could upset expectations.

question.title: Will Larry Elder be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Larry Elder becoming the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, we need to consider several factors: Current standing: Larry Elder is not currently considered a frontrunner for the Republican nomination. He has not officially announced his candidacy for the 2024 presidential race as of now. Name recognition: While Elder has some national recognition due to his radio show and his run for California governor in 2021, his profile is not as high as other potential Republican candidates like Donald Trump, Ron DeSantis, or Nikki Haley. Competition: The Republican field is likely to be crowded with well-known figures who have more established national profiles and support networks. However, this also means that currently more prominent candidates have time to solidify their positions. Given these factors, while it's not impossible for Larry Elder to become the Republican nominee, it seems highly unlikely at this point. He would need to overcome significant obstacles in terms of name recognition, fundraising, and competition from more established candidates.

question.title: Kamala president by Friday?
question.body:
This market will resolve to "Yes" if Vice President Kamala Harris is formally designated as President or Acting President of the United States at any point before July 26, 2024, 11:59 PM ET. Otherwise, this market will resolve to "No".

The primary resolution source for this market will be official information from the US government, however a consensus of credible reporting will also be used.

Resolver

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Kamala Harris becoming President or Acting President by July 26, 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current political landscape: As of now, Joe Biden is the sitting President and there are no immediate indications of him stepping down or being unable to fulfill his duties. 2. Time frame: The question covers a period of about 18 days from now until July 26, 2024. This is a relatively short time frame for such a significant change in leadership. 3. Constitutional procedures: For Harris to become President or Acting President, one of the following scenarios would need to occur: a) Biden resigns (highly unlikely without any current indications) b) Biden is removed from office through impeachment (also highly unlikely in the current political climate) c) Biden becomes incapacitated or dies (while always a possibility, there's no specific reason to believe this is imminent) d) Biden temporarily transfers power to Harris using the 25th Amendment (possible for planned medical procedures, but no such plans have been announced) 4. Biden's health: While Biden is the oldest serving US President and his age is often discussed, there have been no recent reports of severe health issues that would suggest an imminent need for Harris to take over. 5. Political stability: The US government is currently stable, and there are no major crises that might precipitate a sudden change in leadership. 6. Historical precedent: It is extremely rare for a Vice President to suddenly assume the role of President or Acting President without advance warning or extenuating circumstances. Given these factors, the probability of Kamala Harris becoming President or Acting President by July 26, 2024, is very low. While it's not impossible due to unforeseen circumstances, there are no current indications that such a transition is likely or imminent.

question.body: (a) Biden drops out or is otherwise unable to continue the race before July 20, 2024, midnight Eastern Time. metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, we need to consider the likelihood of both events occurring together, as the question requires both conditions to be met for a YES resolution. 1. Biden dropping out before July 20, 2024: - Joe Biden is the incumbent president and the presumptive Democratic nominee for the 2024 election. - While there have been concerns about his age and occasional gaffes, Biden has consistently expressed his intention to run for re-election. - There are no current indications of any severe health issues or scandals that would force him to drop out. - The timeframe is relatively short (less than two weeks from the question's creation date), making a sudden change less likely. - The probability of Biden dropping out in this timeframe seems very low, perhaps around 5%. 2. Kamala Harris not being designated President by July 26, 2024: - If Biden were to drop out, there would be a constitutional process to follow. - As Vice President, Harris would be next in line for the presidency. - However, the formal designation process might take some time, especially if there's any uncertainty or legal challenges. - Given the short timeframe (6 days between Biden potentially dropping out and Harris needing to be designated), there's a small chance that the formal designation might not occur within this window. - If Biden doesn't drop out, this condition would automatically be met. - The probability of Harris not being designated President within this timeframe, given that Biden has dropped out, might be around 20%. For both events to occur, we need Biden to drop out AND Harris not to be designated President within the given timeframe. This is a conjunction of two unlikely events, making the overall probability very low. The probability can be roughly calculated as the product of the two individual probabilities: 0.05 (Biden dropping out) * 0.20 (Harris not being designated, given Biden dropped out) = 0.01 or 1%. question.title: Will either of the following occur before their respective deadlines: (a) Kamala Harris becomes President or Acting President of the United States (b) Joe Biden drops out of the race?
question.body:
(a) Kamala Harris becomes President or Acting President of the United States at any point before July 26, 2024, 11:59 PM ET. This will be confirmed by official information from the US government or a consensus of credible reporting. 

(b) Joe Biden drops out or is otherwise unable to continue the race before July 20, 2024, midnight Eastern Time.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of this question resolving YES, we need to consider both scenarios (a) and (b) separately and then combine their likelihoods. (a) Kamala Harris becoming President or Acting President before July 26, 2024: This scenario is highly unlikely under normal circumstances. For this to happen, President Joe Biden would need to either resign, be removed from office, or become incapacitated. Given that: - Biden's health, while a topic of discussion due to his age, has not shown any severe issues that would likely lead to incapacitation. - There are no serious impeachment proceedings or scandals that might force his resignation. - The 25th Amendment process for temporary transfer of power is rare and usually planned (e.g., for medical procedures). The probability of this occurring is very low, perhaps around 2-3%. (b) Joe Biden dropping out of the race before July 20, 2024: This scenario is also unlikely but slightly more plausible than (a). Factors to consider: - Biden has consistently expressed his intention to run for re-election. - He has the support of the Democratic Party establishment. - Dropping out this late in the election cycle would be highly unusual and potentially damaging to the party. However, there are some factors that could potentially lead to this outcome: - Biden's age and potential health concerns. - Poor polling numbers or a significant political scandal. - Pressure from within the party if they believe he cannot win. Given these factors, the probability of this occurring might be slightly higher, perhaps around 5-7%. Combining these probabilities: The question resolves YES if either of these events occurs. Using the principle of inclusion-exclusion, we can estimate the combined probability as: P(A or B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A and B). Assuming the events are largely independent (which is reasonable given their nature), P(A and B) is very small and can be neglected. Taking the higher end of our estimates for a more conservative approach: P(A or B) ≈ 3% + 7% = 10%. Therefore, I estimate the probability of this question resolving YES to be around 10%.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024:

Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.

The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution.

The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

metadata.chain_of_thought: This is a complex question that involves legal, political, and constitutional considerations. Let's break down the key factors: 1. Legal precedent: In 2023, the Colorado Supreme Court ruled to remove Trump from the state's primary ballot under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment. However, the U.S. Supreme Court unanimously overturned this decision in March 2024, ruling that states cannot unilaterally disqualify candidates for federal office under the 14th Amendment. 2. Supreme Court ruling impact: The Supreme Court's decision sets a strong precedent that makes it significantly less likely for any state to successfully remove Trump from their primary ballot under the 14th Amendment. 3. Time frame: The question resolves on July 15, 2024, which is after the primary season for most states. This reduces the window of opportunity for such an action to occur and be in effect by the resolution date. 4. Political climate: Despite ongoing legal challenges and controversies surrounding Trump, there is strong support for him within the Republican party, making it politically difficult for Republican-controlled states to attempt such a move. 5. Legal challenges: Any attempt to remove Trump from a ballot would likely face immediate legal challenges, which could prevent it from being in effect by the resolution date. 6. State-level actions: While some states might attempt to remove Trump from their ballots, the Supreme Court ruling makes it highly unlikely that such attempts would succeed or remain in effect by July 15, 2024. Given these factors, especially the Supreme Court's ruling, it seems highly improbable that Trump will be successfully removed or blocked from any state's primary election ballot under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment by the resolution date. The Supreme Court's decision effectively closes this avenue for disqualification, barring any extraordinary and unforeseen circumstances.

question.title: Will INC form the government after the next Indian general election in 2024?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if the INC has a member sworn in as the next Indian Prime Minister following the next general elections. All other parties will resolve as **No**.

This question will resolve for the next general election occurring after June 1, 2022 (currently expected for May 2024).

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of the Indian National Congress (INC) forming the government after the next Indian general election in 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current political landscape: The Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) led by Prime Minister Narendra Modi has been in power since 2014 and won a significant majority in the 2019 elections. The INC, the main opposition party, has struggled to regain its former prominence. 2. Recent electoral performance: The INC has faced significant losses in recent state elections and has not shown strong signs of a nationwide resurgence. 3. Leadership issues: The INC has been grappling with internal leadership challenges, particularly regarding the role of the Gandhi family. This has affected the party's ability to present a united front and a clear alternative to the BJP. 4. BJP's strengths: The BJP has a strong organizational structure, significant financial resources, and the personal popularity of PM Modi, which continues to be a major factor in Indian politics. 5. Anti-incumbency: While anti-incumbency could potentially work against the BJP, it hasn't significantly impacted their performance in recent elections. 6. Opposition unity: The ability of opposition parties, including the INC, to form a united front against the BJP will be crucial. However, past attempts at such alliances have had limited success. 7. Time until elections: With about a year left until the expected election date, there is still time for political dynamics to shift, but major changes would need to occur for the INC to significantly improve its position. 8. Economic and social factors: The state of the economy, handling of issues like inflation, unemployment, and social tensions could influence voter sentiment, but it's unclear if these factors will substantially benefit the INC. Given these factors, while it's not impossible for the INC to form the government after the 2024 elections, it appears highly unlikely based on the current political scenario. The INC would need to overcome significant challenges and see a dramatic shift in voter sentiment to achieve this outcome.

question.title: Will the New York Knicks win the 2024 NBA Finals?

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of the New York Knicks winning the 2024 NBA Finals, we need to consider several factors: 1. question.title: Will at least 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early?
question.body:
Context from Politico:

Dozens of House Democrats are organizing a plan to speak out against their own party’s effort to seal President Joe Biden’s nomination sooner than originally planned, which they argue stifles the intense ongoing debate about his candidacy, according to a lawmaker involved in the effort.

A drafted letter, circulated by Rep. Jared Huffman (D-Calif.) and obtained by POLITICO, offers the first public signal from Democrats since the weekend’s attempted assassination on former President Donald Trump that scores of their own members remain deeply unsettled about the future of Biden’s candidacy.

“It’s a really bad move by the DNC. Somebody thinks it’s a clever way to lock down debate and I guess by dint of sheer force, achieve unity, but it doesn’t work that way,” Huffman said in an interview. He declined to confirm the existence of a letter.

This market resolves YES if a public letter opposing the early nomination plan is signed by at least 20 House Members or Senators who caucus with the Democratic Party before market close at the end of Sunday, July 21st. 

Multiple such letters with a combined total of 20 lawmaker's signatures would also be sufficient to resolve this market to YES. 

If these criteria are not met by market close, this market resolves NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of this event occurring, we need to consider several factors: 1. Existing opposition: The context already mentions that 'dozens of House Democrats' are organizing to speak out against the early nomination plan. This suggests there is significant opposition within the party. 2. Time frame: The market closes on July 21st, giving about a week for the letter to be finalized and signed. This is a relatively short period, but not impossibly so for organizing such an effort. 3. Number of signatures required: The threshold of 20 signatures is relatively low, considering there are currently 213 Democratic Representatives in the House and 48 Democratic Senators (plus 3 Independents who caucus with Democrats). 4. Motivation: The opposition seems to stem from concerns about stifling debate and achieving forced unity, which could be strong motivators for lawmakers to take action. 5. Public nature: The requirement for a 'public' letter adds a layer of complexity, as some lawmakers might be hesitant to openly oppose the party leadership. 6. Political climate: The attempted assassination of former President Trump might make some Democrats more cautious about appearing divided, potentially reducing willingness to sign. 7. Rep. Huffman's involvement: While he declined to confirm the letter's existence, his willingness to speak about the opposition suggests the effort is serious. Given these factors, it seems quite plausible that 20 or more Democratic lawmakers would sign such a letter. The existing 'dozens' of organizers suggest that reaching 20 signatures is achievable. However, the short timeframe and the public nature of the opposition introduce some uncertainty.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (1) 10 or more Democratic Senators call for Biden to drop out before July 20, and (2) fewer than 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early?
question.body:
(1) Will 10 or more Democratic Senators call for Biden to drop out before July 20?
Resolution source: https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2024/us/elections/biden-drop-out-democrats.html

If at any point before midnight July 20 Central Time, it shows 10 or more Dem Senators, this market will resolve to yes. Otherwise, it will resolve to no.

(2) Will fewer than 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early?
Context from Politico:

Dozens of House Democrats are organizing a plan to speak out against their own party’s effort to seal President Joe Biden’s nomination sooner than originally planned, which they argue stifles the intense ongoing debate about his candidacy, according to a lawmaker involved in the effort.

A drafted letter, circulated by Rep. Jared Huffman (D-Calif.) and obtained by POLITICO, offers the first public signal from Democrats since the weekend’s attempted assassination on former President Donald Trump that scores of their own members remain deeply unsettled about the future of Biden’s candidacy.

“It’s a really bad move by the DNC. Somebody thinks it’s a clever way to lock down debate and I guess by dint of sheer force, achieve unity, but it doesn’t work that way,” Huffman said in an interview. He declined to confirm the existence of a letter.

This market resolves YES if a public letter opposing the early nomination plan is signed by fewer than 20 House Members or Senators who caucus with the Democratic Party before market close at the end of Sunday, July 21st. 

Multiple such letters with a combined total of fewer than 20 lawmaker's signatures would also be sufficient to resolve this market to YES. 

If these criteria are not met by market close, this market resolves NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of both events occurring, we need to analyze each part separately and then consider their joint probability. 1. 10 or more Democratic Senators calling for Biden to drop out before July 20: This scenario seems highly unlikely. As of now, there has been no significant movement among Democratic Senators calling for Biden to drop out. Biden is the incumbent president and the presumptive nominee for the Democratic Party. While there have been concerns about his age and some policy decisions, there hasn't been a widespread revolt against his candidacy within the party leadership. The timeframe (until July 20) is also quite short, making it even less likely for such a dramatic shift to occur. I would estimate the probability of this happening at around 0.05 or 5%. 2. Fewer than 20 House/Senate Democrats signing a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early: This scenario is more plausible. The context provided indicates that there is some opposition to the DNC's plan to seal Biden's nomination early. Rep. Jared Huffman is circulating a letter, which suggests there is some level of discontent. However, the question is whether this discontent will translate to fewer than 20 signatures. Given that there are hundreds of Democratic members in the House and Senate combined, it's quite possible that 20 or more might sign such a letter. The fact that 'dozens' of House Democrats are organizing suggests that the number could easily exceed 20. I would estimate the probability of fewer than 20 signing at around 0.3 or 30%. For both events to occur, we need to multiply these probabilities: 0.05 * 0.3 = 0.015 or 1.5%. This is a very low probability, primarily driven by the unlikelihood of 10 or more Democratic Senators calling for Biden to drop out.

question.title: Will either of the following occur before July 21st: (a) At least 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early (b) 10 or more Democratic Senators call for Biden to drop out?
question.body:
(a) At least 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early: 

Context from Politico: Dozens of House Democrats are organizing a plan to speak out against their own party’s effort to seal President Joe Biden’s nomination sooner than originally planned, which they argue stifles the intense ongoing debate about his candidacy, according to a lawmaker involved in the effort. A drafted letter, circulated by Rep. Jared Huffman (D-Calif.) and obtained by POLITICO, offers the first public signal from Democrats since the weekend’s attempted assassination on former President Donald Trump that scores of their own members remain deeply unsettled about the future of Biden’s candidacy. “It’s a really bad move by the DNC. Somebody thinks it’s a clever way to lock down debate and I guess by dint of sheer force, achieve unity, but it doesn’t work that way,” Huffman said in an interview. He declined to confirm the existence of a letter. This resolves YES if a public letter opposing the early nomination plan is signed by at least 20 House Members or Senators who caucus with the Democratic Party before market close at the end of Sunday, July 21st. Multiple such letters with a combined total of 20 lawmaker's signatures would also be sufficient to resolve this to YES. If these criteria are not met by market close, this resolves NO.

(b) 10 or more Democratic Senators call for Biden to drop out before July 20: 

Resolution source: https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2024/us/elections/biden-drop-out-democrats.html. If at any point before midnight July 20 Central Time, it shows 10 or more Dem Senators, this will resolve to yes. Otherwise, it will resolve to no.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of this question resolving YES, we need to consider both parts (a) and (b) separately and then combine their likelihoods. (a) At least 20 House/Senate Democrats signing a public letter opposing early virtual nomination of Biden: - There's already a draft letter circulating, initiated by Rep. Jared Huffman. - The article mentions 'scores' of Democrats are unsettled about Biden's candidacy, suggesting significant discontent. - However, publicly opposing the party's presumptive nominee is a bold move that many might be hesitant to make. - The timeframe is relatively short (about a week), which might limit the ability to gather signatures. - Given these factors, I'd estimate a moderate probability of this occurring, perhaps around 30-40%. (b) 10 or more Democratic Senators calling for Biden to drop out: - This is a much more drastic action than opposing early nomination. - There's no current indication of any Democratic Senators calling for Biden to drop out. - The timeframe is even shorter for this option (until July 20). - This would be an extraordinary event in modern politics. - Given these factors, I'd estimate a very low probability of this occurring, perhaps around 1-2%. Combining these probabilities: The question resolves YES if either (a) or (b) occurs. Using the principle of probability of either event occurring, we can calculate: P(A or B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A and B) Let's use the higher estimates for a conservative approach: P(A) = 0.40 P(B) = 0.02 P(A and B) is likely very small, let's estimate 0.005 0.40 + 0.02 - 0.005 = 0.415 Therefore, I estimate there's about a 41.5% chance of either of these events occurring before the specified dates.

question.title: Will Latvia qualify for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if Latvia participates in a Semi-final and is then officially announced by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) as having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final. If Latvia does not qualify, the question will resolve as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess Latvia's chances of qualifying for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. Historical performance: Latvia has had mixed results in Eurovision. They last qualified for the Grand Final in 2016, and have failed to qualify in the last seven contests (2017-2023). This suggests a recent struggle to make it through the semi-finals. 2. Song selection: The quality and appeal of Latvia's entry for 2024 will be crucial. As of now (April 2023), Latvia has not yet selected their entry for 2024, so we can't judge based on the specific song. 3. Semi-final draw: The allocation of countries in each semi-final can impact qualification chances. Some semi-finals may be more competitive than others. 4. Voting patterns: Latvia tends to receive support from neighboring Baltic countries and the Nordic region, but this hasn't been enough to secure qualification in recent years. 5. Changes in format or voting system: Any potential changes to the Eurovision format or voting system for 2024 could impact qualification chances, but no major changes have been announced as of now. 6. Improvement efforts: Given Latvia's recent string of non-qualifications, there may be increased efforts to improve their chances, such as investing more in song selection or staging. 7. Competition level: The overall quality of entries from other countries in 2024 will affect Latvia's relative chances of qualifying. Considering these factors, Latvia's chances of qualifying are not particularly high based on recent history. However, Eurovision results can be unpredictable, and with a strong entry and performance, qualification is certainly possible. The lack of information about their 2024 entry makes it difficult to make a confident prediction. Given the recent track record and the uncertainties involved, I would estimate a lower probability of Latvia qualifying for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024.

In 2023, Belgium qualified and finished 7th overall, indicating a strong recent performance. Latvia, on the other hand, has struggled, qualifying only once in the last 10 contests and failing to qualify in 2023. The quality of entries is crucial, and while we don't know the specific songs yet, Belgium's recent track record suggests a good chance of qualification. Latvia's recent history indicates they are less likely to qualify. Considering these factors, I believe there's a moderate to good chance that both conditions will be met – Belgium qualifying and Latvia not qualifying.

question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if either of the following occurs: (a) Latvia participates in a Semi-final and is officially announced by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) as having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final. (b) Belgium participates in a Semi-final and is officially announced by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) as having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final. metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of either Latvia or Belgium qualifying for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. Historical performance: Latvia has qualified for the Grand Final 6 times out of 14 attempts since the introduction of semi-finals in 2004. Belgium has qualified 8 times out of 15 attempts in the same period. 2. Recent performance: Latvia has failed to qualify for the Grand Final in the last seven consecutive years (2017-2023). Belgium has had mixed results, qualifying in 2021 and 2022, but failing to qualify in 2023. 3. Eurovision voting patterns: Both countries have struggled with consistent support from neighboring countries or diaspora voting. Neither country is considered a powerhouse in the competition. 4. However, both countries have shown the ability to produce competitive entries in the past. 5. Combined chances: Having two countries increases the overall probability of a positive outcome, as only one needs to qualify for the question to resolve as Yes. Considering these factors, Belgium appears to have a slightly better chance of qualifying based on recent history. Latvia's prolonged absence from the Grand Final is concerning, but they have shown the ability to qualify in the past. The combined probability of at least one of these countries qualifying is higher than their individual chances. Given the historical data, recent performances, and the fact that we have two chances for a positive outcome, I would estimate the probability of either Latvia or Belgium qualifying for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024 to be moderately likely.

question.title: Will 10 or more Democratic Senators call for Biden to drop out before July 20?
question.body:
Resolution source: https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2024/us/elections/biden-drop-out-democrats.html

If at any point before midnight July 20 Central Time, it shows 10 or more Dem Senators, this market will resolve to yes. Otherwise, it will resolve to no.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of this event occurring, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current political climate: As of now, there is no significant movement or public discourse among Democratic Senators calling for Biden to drop out of the 2024 presidential race. 2. Biden's performance and approval ratings: While Biden's approval ratings have been relatively low, they haven't reached a critical point where his own party would widely call for his withdrawal. 3. Time frame: The resolution date is July 20, which gives only about 18 days for this scenario to unfold. This is a very short time for such a dramatic political shift. 4. Party unity: Democrats are generally focused on maintaining unity against the Republican opposition, especially in an election year. Calling for the incumbent president to drop out would be seen as extremely divisive. 5. Lack of clear alternative: There is no prominent Democratic figure currently positioned as a clear alternative to Biden, which makes it less likely for Senators to call for his withdrawal without a backup plan. 6. Historical precedent: It's extremely rare for a sitting president's own party to call for them to drop out of a re-election bid, especially this close to the election. 7. Age and health concerns: While there have been discussions about Biden's age, these haven't translated into widespread calls for him to step aside from within the party. 8. Potential for unforeseen events: While unlikely, there's always a possibility of a major scandal or health issue that could rapidly change the situation. Given these factors, it seems highly improbable that 10 or more Democratic Senators would call for Biden to drop out in such a short timeframe. The likelihood of this happening is very low, but not absolutely zero due to the unpredictable nature of politics.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) another Democratic party presidential debate occurs before the 2024 Democratic National Convention, and (b) fewer than 10 Democratic Senators call for Biden to drop out before July 20?
question.body:
(a) Resolves YES if there is a debate between potential Democratic nominees (e.g. Harris, Newsom, Whitmer, Biden etc.) prior to the 2024 Democratic National Convention. Resolves NO otherwise.

(b) If at any point before midnight July 20 Central Time, the New York Times source shows fewer than 10 Democratic Senators calling for Biden to drop out, this resolves to YES. Otherwise, it resolves to NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
To answer this question, we need to consider both parts (a) and (b) separately and then combine our assessments.

(a) Another Democratic party presidential debate before the 2024 Democratic National Convention:
As of now, Joe Biden is the presumptive Democratic nominee for the 2024 presidential election. Typically, when an incumbent president is running for re-election, their party doesn't hold primary debates. However, there have been some concerns about Biden's age and fitness for office, which could potentially lead to calls for debates. Despite this, the Democratic National Committee (DNC) has not scheduled any debates, and Biden's campaign has not expressed interest in participating in one. The convention is scheduled for August 19-22, 2024, leaving limited time for organizing a debate. Given these factors, the likelihood of a debate occurring seems low.

(b) Fewer than 10 Democratic Senators calling for Biden to drop out before July 20:
As of now, there hasn't been a significant movement among Democratic Senators calling for Biden to drop out. While there have been some concerns about his age and approval ratings, most Democratic Senators have publicly supported Biden's re-election bid. It would be a major political shift for 10 or more Senators to call for the sitting president from their own party to drop out. Such a move would be highly unusual and potentially damaging to the party. Given the short timeframe (until July 20) and the current lack of public dissent, it seems highly likely that fewer than 10 Democratic Senators will call for Biden to drop out.

Combining these assessments:
For the overall question to resolve as YES, both (a) and (b) need to occur. While (b) seems highly likely, (a) appears unlikely. The combination of these two events makes the overall probability lower than either event individually.

question.body:

The timeframe is very short (less than 3 weeks from the question's creation date). 2. Biden is the incumbent president and has strong support within the Democratic party. 3. There have been no major scandals or health issues that would prompt such a drastic action. 4. Democratic Senators would be hesitant to undermine their party's unity so close to an election. Combining these probabilities, we need to consider that only one of these events needs to occur for the question to resolve YES. Using the principle of addition for mutually exclusive events (which is a simplification but reasonable in this case), we can add the probabilities: 1% (scenario a) + 7.5% (average of 5-10% for scenario b) = 8.5%. question.title: Will Donald Trump be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Donald Trump is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question may consider new candidates added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Donald Trump becoming the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, we need to consider several factors: 1. Historical precedent: Trump was the Republican nominee in 2016 and 2020, which gives him a strong base of support within the party. 2. Current polling: As of 2023, Trump consistently leads in polls for the Republican primary, often by significant margins over other potential candidates. 3. Loyal base: Trump maintains a dedicated and enthusiastic base of supporters within the Republican Party. 4. Name recognition: Trump has unparalleled name recognition among potential Republican candidates. 5. Fundraising ability: Trump has demonstrated a strong ability to raise funds for his campaigns. 6. Challenges: a. Legal issues: Trump faces several ongoing legal challenges that could potentially impact his candidacy. b. Party establishment: Some Republican Party leaders have expressed a desire to move on from Trump. c. Age: Trump will be 78 in 2024, which could be a concern for some voters. 7. Competition: While there are other candidates in the race (e.g., Ron DeSantis, Nikki Haley), none have yet shown the ability to consistently challenge Trump's frontrunner status. 8. Time until convention: The Republican National Convention is still some time away, allowing for potential shifts in the political landscape. Given these factors, Trump appears to be in a strong position to secure the nomination. His consistent lead in polls, loyal base, and previous nominations are significant advantages. However, the legal challenges he faces and potential party establishment resistance introduce some uncertainty.

question.title: Will Ted Cruz be the Republican nominee and Donald Trump not be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if BOTH of the following conditions are met: (1) Ted Cruz is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, AND (2) Donald Trump is not selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. The resolution of this question is not affected by who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the Republican National Convention. New candidates may be considered in the future, but both conditions must be simultaneously satisfied for a **Yes** resolution.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of this scenario, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current polling and support: As of now, Donald Trump is the clear frontrunner for the 2024 Republican nomination. He consistently leads in national polls and state-level surveys by a significant margin. 2. Ted Cruz's position: While Ted Cruz is a prominent Republican figure, he has not announced a 2024 presidential run and currently shows no signs of challenging Trump. 3. Historical precedent: It's extremely rare for a former president to seek re-nomination and not receive it. The party typically rallies around such a figure. 4. Republican party dynamics: The GOP base remains largely supportive of Trump, and many party officials and donors are aligned with him. 5. Legal challenges: While Trump faces various legal issues, they have not significantly diminished his support among Republican voters so far. 6. Potential for unexpected events: There's always a possibility of unforeseen circumstances that could dramatically alter the political landscape before the convention. Given these factors, the scenario described in the question is highly unlikely. For Ted Cruz to become the nominee while Trump is not would require a series of extraordinary events: 1. Trump would need to be removed from contention (e.g., due to legal issues or a major scandal). 2. The party would need to reject other prominent candidates who are more actively pursuing the nomination (e.g., Ron DeSantis, Mike Pence). 3. Ted Cruz would need to enter the race and quickly gain overwhelming support. While not impossible, this chain of events is extremely improbable. Trump's grip on the party remains strong, and even if he were to falter, there are other candidates better positioned than Cruz to take advantage.

question.title: Will either Donald Trump or Ted Cruz be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if either Donald Trump or Ted Cruz is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question may consider new candidates added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of either Donald Trump or Ted Cruz becoming the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, we need to consider several factors: 1. Donald Trump's position: As of now, Trump is the front-runner for the Republican nomination. He has maintained a strong base of support within the Republican Party and has consistently led in polls for the 2024 primary. His influence on the party remains significant, despite legal challenges and controversies. 2. Ted Cruz's position: While Cruz ran for the nomination in 2016 and has maintained a high profile in the Senate, he has not announced a 2024 presidential run as of now. His chances appear much slimmer compared to Trump's. 3. Other candidates: Several other Republicans have announced their candidacy or are considering running, including Ron DeSantis, Nikki Haley, and Mike Pence. DeSantis, in particular, has been seen as a strong potential challenger to Trump. 4. Party dynamics: The Republican Party has largely aligned itself with Trump's policies and rhetoric since 2016. However, there is a growing faction within the party that seeks to move beyond Trump. 5. External factors: Ongoing legal issues facing Trump could potentially impact his candidacy, although they have not significantly diminished his support so far. 6. Historical precedent: It's rare for a former president to reclaim the nomination, but not unprecedented (e.g., Grover Cleveland). Given these factors, Donald Trump has a high probability of securing the nomination. Ted Cruz's chances are much lower, but not zero. The combined probability of either of them becoming the nominee is largely driven by Trump's strong position.

question.title: Will Kamala's odds of winning increase over the next week according to Nate Silver's model?
question.body:
Resolves YES if the Electoral College probability for Harris in Nate Silver's model is >46.6% on Friday August 9th at 8:40 PM. Resolves NO otherwise.

Link: https://www.natesilver.net/p/nate-silver-2024-president-election-polls-model

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current situation: As of the question's creation date (July 3, 2024), Kamala Harris is not the official Democratic nominee for the 2024 presidential election. Joe Biden is the incumbent president and presumptive nominee. 2. Time frame: The resolution date is set for August 10, 2024, which is over a month after the question was created. This gives time for potential changes in the political landscape. 3. Nate Silver's model: Nate Silver is known for his accurate political predictions and data-driven approach. His model likely takes into account various factors such as polling data, economic indicators, and historical trends. 4. Threshold: The question resolves YES if Harris's Electoral College probability is greater than 46.6% on August 9th at 8:40 PM. 5. Political context: For Harris to have such high odds, there would likely need to be a significant change in the Democratic primary process or Biden's status as the presumptive nominee. Given these factors, I believe it is unlikely that Kamala Harris's odds of winning will increase to over 46.6% in Nate Silver's model by August 9th. Here's why: a) Biden is the incumbent president and presumptive nominee, making a sudden shift to Harris unlikely without extraordinary circumstances. b) For Harris to have such high odds, she would need to become the Democratic nominee or be perceived as the de facto nominee due to some unforeseen event. c) Even if such an event occurred, it would take time for polls and other data to reflect this change, and for Nate Silver's model to incorporate this new information. d) The 46.6% threshold is quite high for a candidate who is not currently the presumptive nominee. However, we cannot completely rule out the possibility of unexpected events that could dramatically change the political landscape. Such events could include health issues for Biden, a major scandal, or Biden deciding to step aside for some reason. Considering all these factors, I believe there is a low probability of this event occurring, but it's not impossible.

question.title: Will OpenAI's ChatGPT be generally available in the European Union on June 30, 2024?
question.body:
The question resolves as **YES** if [ChatGPT](chat.openai.com) is generally available in the EU on June 30, 2024, and **NO** otherwise.

"Generally available" here means that the default state for people in the EU is that they can access it without a VPN (possibly requiring paying for it.) If unavailable in certain EU countries (as was the case in Italy in early 2023), or unavailable to (for example) minors, this will still resolve positively, assuming at least >50% of the population can use it.

"ChatGPT" here refers to the general web interface (not the API) for interacting with GPT models. Still resolves positively if the name or website has changed, as long as OpenAI's service is substantially the same (entering queries to systems based on Large Language Models).

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of ChatGPT being generally available in the European Union on June 30, 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. OpenAI's expansion plans: OpenAI has shown a strong interest in global expansion and has been working to make ChatGPT available in more countries. 3. EU regulations: The EU has been developing AI regulations, including the AI Act, which could impact ChatGPT's availability. However, these regulations are more likely to impose requirements on AI systems rather than outright banning them. 4. OpenAI's compliance efforts: OpenAI has demonstrated willingness to work with regulators to ensure compliance. They temporarily suspended service in Italy to address concerns and resumed operations after making necessary adjustments. 5. Time frame: The question is about availability on June 30, 2024, which is more than a year away. This gives OpenAI ample time to address any regulatory concerns and make necessary adjustments. 6. Public demand: There is significant public and business interest in AI tools like ChatGPT in the EU, which creates pressure for continued availability. 7. Competition: Other AI companies are also expanding in the EU market, which may motivate OpenAI to maintain its presence. Given these factors, it seems highly likely that ChatGPT will be generally available in the EU on June 30, 2024. The main risks are potential regulatory hurdles, but OpenAI has shown the ability to navigate these successfully so far. The long time frame also allows for addressing any issues that may arise.
