question.title: Will either OpenAI or Anthropic publish a report with results from external red-teaming of their models for safety by June 30, 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as **YES** if, by June 30, 2024, either of the following occurs: (a) OpenAI publishes a *public* report with the results from an *external* party red-teaming the safety of one of their AI models. (b) Anthropic publishes a *public* report with the results from an *external* party red-teaming the safety of one of their AI models.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of this event occurring, we need to consider several factors: 1. Industry trends: There's a growing emphasis on AI safety and transparency in the AI industry, especially for leading companies like OpenAI and Anthropic. 2. Previous behavior: Both OpenAI and Anthropic have shown commitment to AI safety in the past. OpenAI has published safety-related reports, and Anthropic was founded with a focus on developing safe and ethical AI. 3. Timeframe: The question gives almost a full year (until June 30, 2024) for this to occur, which is a considerable amount of time in the fast-moving AI field. 4. External pressure: As AI capabilities grow, there's likely to be increased pressure from governments, academia, and the public for transparency and safety assessments. 5. Competitive advantage: Publishing such reports could be seen as a way to demonstrate leadership in AI safety, potentially giving either company a competitive edge. 6. Resource allocation: Both companies have significant resources and could likely arrange for external red-teaming if they prioritize it. 7. Potential drawbacks: The companies might be hesitant to publish such reports if they reveal vulnerabilities or proprietary information. 8. Only one company needs to do it: The question resolves as YES if either OpenAI or Anthropic publishes such a report, increasing the likelihood. Given these factors, I believe there's a good chance that at least one of these companies will publish an external red-teaming report by the specified date. The growing importance of AI safety, the companies' past behaviors, and the extended timeframe all point towards a higher probability. However, potential concerns about revealing vulnerabilities or proprietary information might act as a deterrent.

question.title: [Metaculus] Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democra...nomination for President?
question.body:
Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?

Resolves the same as the original on Metaculus.

(https://www.metaculus.com/questions/question_embed/25755/?theme=dark)Resolution criteria

This question will resolve as Yes if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle.

To qualify for a Yes resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle.

If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as No.

Fine print and additional background information can be found on Metaculus.

Once the original resolves, its resolution will be applied to this market automatically. Trustworthy-ish users are encouraged to resolve this market before then if the outcome is known and unambiguous. Feel free to ping @jskf to request early resolution or to report issues.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Joe Biden announcing he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President before July 15, 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. Incumbent advantage: Historically, sitting presidents rarely decline to run for a second term unless facing significant health issues or extreme unpopularity. Biden is the incumbent, which gives him a strong position within the party. 2. Age and health concerns: Biden will be 81 at the time of the 2024 election, making him the oldest president in U.S. history. There are ongoing concerns about his age and mental acuity, which could potentially influence his decision. 3. Current statements and actions: As of now, Biden has repeatedly stated his intention to run for re-election. His campaign has already begun fundraising and organizing for 2024. 4. Party support: The Democratic Party leadership has largely rallied behind Biden, and there are no strong challengers within the party at this time. 5. Political climate: While Biden's approval ratings have been relatively low, they are not at a level that would typically cause an incumbent to step aside. 6. Time frame: The question asks about an announcement before July 15, 2024, which is very close to the Democratic National Convention (typically held in August). It's unlikely that a sitting president would wait until so late in the process to announce they're not running. 7. Historical precedent: The last incumbent president to not seek re-election was Lyndon B. Johnson in 1968, and that was under very different circumstances. Given these factors, it seems highly unlikely that Biden would announce he's not accepting the nomination. While concerns about his age and health are real, they don't appear to be severe enough at this point to force him out of the race. The late date in the election cycle also makes it improbable that he would make such an announcement so close to the convention.

question.title: Will the Republican Party retain Ohio's 6th congressional district in the 2024 special election and Joe Biden not announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?
question.body:
Will both of the following occur: (a) The Republican Party retains Ohio's 6th congressional district (previously held by Bill Johnson) in the 2024 special election, and (b) Joe Biden does not announce before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?

Resolution criteria:

1. The first component will resolve as Yes if credible sources report that a person representing the Republican Party has won the special election for Ohio's 6th district. If popular sources are in disagreement, an Ohio State source or statement will be used. If no election is held before January 1, 2025, the question is annulled.

2. The second component will resolve as Yes if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign does not make a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle. If such a definitive statement is made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this component will resolve as No.

This combined question will resolve as Yes if both components resolve as Yes.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, we need to consider both components separately and then combine their probabilities. 1. Republican Party retaining Ohio's 6th congressional district: Ohio's 6th district has been a Republican stronghold for many years. Bill Johnson, who recently resigned, had held the seat since 2011. In the 2022 election, Johnson won with 67.4% of the vote, indicating strong Republican support in the district. Given the historical voting patterns and the current political climate, it's highly likely that the Republicans will retain this seat in the special election. I would estimate the probability of this occurring at around 0.9. 2. Joe Biden not announcing before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic nomination: As of now (January 2024), Joe Biden has repeatedly stated his intention to run for re-election in 2024. He has already filed paperwork with the Federal Election Commission and has been actively campaigning. While there have been concerns about his age and some calls for a younger candidate, Biden and his team have remained committed to his re-election bid. It's unlikely that he would suddenly announce he won't accept the nomination, especially this late in the process. The deadline of July 15, 2024, is very close to the Democratic National Convention, making it even less likely for Biden to back out at that point. I would estimate the probability of Biden not making such an announcement before July 15, 2024, at around 0.95. To calculate the probability of both events occurring, we multiply their individual probabilities: 0.9 * 0.95 = 0.855. Therefore, the probability of both events occurring is approximately 0.855 or 85.5%.

question.title: Will either Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic nomination for President, or will the Republican Party retain Ohio's 6th congressional district in the 2024 special election?
question.body: Will either of the following occur: (a) Joe Biden announce before 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle, with a definitive, public, official announcement that is unambiguous and conclusive, or (b) the Republican Party retain Ohio's 6th congressional district in the 2024 special election, as reported by credible sources, or if there is disagreement, by an Ohio State source or statement? If no election is held before January 1, 2025, the question regarding Ohio's 6th district is annulled.

metadata.chain_of_thought: This question requires evaluating two separate events, and if either occurs, the question resolves as YES. Let's analyze each part: a) Joe Biden announcing he won't accept the Democratic nomination: Biden is the incumbent president and has already announced his intention to run for re-election. While there have been concerns about his age and approval ratings, he has consistently reaffirmed his commitment to running. It's very rare for an incumbent president to drop out of the race, especially this late in the election cycle. The deadline (July 15, 2024) is very close to the Democratic National Convention, making a last-minute change extremely unlikely. Probability of this occurring: Very low, around 5-10%. b) Republican Party retaining Ohio's 6th congressional district: Ohio's 6th district has been a Republican stronghold for many years. In the 2022 election, the Republican candidate won with 67.9% of the vote. Ohio has been trending more Republican in recent years. Special elections can sometimes produce surprising results, but given the district's history, a Republican victory is highly likely. Probability of this occurring: Very high, around 85-90%. Given that only one of these events needs to occur for the question to resolve as YES, and the second event (Republican retention of OH-6) is highly likely, the overall probability is quite high.

question.title: Will Vivek Ramaswamy be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Vivek Ramaswamy is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently below; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Vivek Ramaswamy becoming the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current standing: As of now, Vivek Ramaswamy is a relatively new and lesser-known figure in national politics. He has gained some attention for his conservative views and business background, but he lacks the political experience and name recognition of many other potential candidates. 2. Competition: The Republican field for 2024 is likely to be crowded with more established politicians. Former President Donald Trump, Florida Governor Ron DeSantis, and other high-profile Republicans are expected to run or are already running. These candidates have stronger bases of support and greater financial resources. 3. Polling: In current polls for the Republican primary, Ramaswamy consistently ranks low, often in the low single digits. This suggests he has a long way to go to become a frontrunner. 4. Fundraising: While Ramaswamy has personal wealth, his campaign fundraising has not been on par with top-tier candidates. This could limit his ability to compete effectively across multiple states. 5. Media attention: Ramaswamy has received some media coverage, but not nearly as much as the leading candidates. This makes it harder for him to build name recognition and support. 6. Party establishment: The Republican Party establishment tends to favor candidates with more traditional political backgrounds. Ramaswamy's outsider status could work against him in securing party support. 7. Time until convention: The Republican National Convention is still some time away, which theoretically gives Ramaswamy time to build support. However, it also gives established candidates time to solidify their positions. 8. Historical precedent: It's extremely rare for a political newcomer with no prior elected office to secure a major party nomination, though not impossible (as demonstrated by Trump in 2016). Given these factors, while it's not impossible for Ramaswamy to secure the nomination, it appears highly unlikely. He would need to overcome significant obstacles and see a dramatic shift in his support and standing within the party.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) Rishi Sunak fails to be elected in the 2024 UK General Election (b) Vivek Ramaswamy is not the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
(a) This question resolves as **Yes** if for any reason Rishi Sunak fails to be elected as a Member of Parliament in the July 4 2024 UK general election. If Sunak is elected as a Member of Parliament for any constituency in the July 4 2024 UK general election, this question will resolve as **No**. Resolution should cite [credible](https://www.metaculus.com/help/faq/#definitions) media reports, or an official announcement from the returning officer of the constituency in which Sunak is a candidate (if he is a candidate in any constituency).

(b) This question will resolve as **Yes** if Vivek Ramaswamy is not selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. If any other candidate is selected, this question will resolve as **Yes**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently below; other options may be added in the future. For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of both events occurring, we need to analyze each part separately and then combine their probabilities. (a) Rishi Sunak failing to be elected in the 2024 UK General Election: Rishi Sunak is the current Prime Minister of the UK and leader of the Conservative Party. He represents the constituency of Richmond (Yorks), which is considered a safe Conservative seat. Historically, sitting Prime Ministers are rarely unseated in their own constituencies. However, the Conservative Party has been facing challenges in recent polls, and there's growing dissatisfaction with the government's performance. Despite this, it's still highly unlikely that Sunak would lose his seat. The probability of Sunak failing to be elected is low, perhaps around 10-15%. (b) Vivek Ramaswamy not being the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election: Vivek Ramaswamy is a relatively new face in national politics and is considered a long-shot candidate for the Republican nomination. The Republican field is currently dominated by more established figures like Donald Trump and Ron DeSantis. While Ramaswamy has gained some attention, he lacks the name recognition, political experience, and broad support base that typically characterize successful nominees. The probability of Ramaswamy not being the nominee is very high, perhaps around 95-98%. For both events to occur, we need both (a) and (b) to happen. Since these events are independent, we multiply their probabilities. However, since we're asked about the probability of both occurring, we're essentially looking at the probability of (b) occurring (Ramaswamy not being the nominee) multiplied by the small chance of (a) occurring (Sunak failing to be elected). Given the high likelihood of (b) and the low likelihood of (a), the overall probability of both events occurring is still relatively low, but higher than the probability of Sunak losing his seat alone.

question.title: Will either Vivek Ramaswamy be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election or Rishi Sunak fail to be elected in the 2024 UK General Election?
question.body:
This question resolves as **Yes** if either of the following occurs:

1. Vivek Ramaswamy is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. This is determined by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention), regardless of who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election.

2. Rishi Sunak fails to be elected as a Member of Parliament in the July 4 2024 UK general election for any reason. If Sunak is elected as a Member of Parliament for any constituency in this election, this part of the question will resolve as **No**.

Resolution for the second part should cite [credible](https://www.metaculus.com/help/faq/#definitions) media reports, or an official announcement from the returning officer of the constituency in which Sunak is a candidate (if he is a candidate in any constituency).

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, we need to consider both parts separately and then combine their probabilities. 1. Vivek Ramaswamy becoming the Republican nominee: Vivek Ramaswamy is a relatively new face in politics, having announced his candidacy for the 2024 Republican presidential nomination in February 2023. While he has gained some attention for his conservative views and business background, he is still considered a long-shot candidate. The Republican field is likely to be crowded, with more established politicians like Donald Trump, Ron DeSantis, and others having much higher name recognition and support within the party. Given his current position and the strength of other potential candidates, the probability of Ramaswamy becoming the nominee is very low, perhaps around 1-2%. 2. Rishi Sunak failing to be elected in the 2024 UK General Election: Rishi Sunak is currently the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom and leader of the Conservative Party. While his party has been facing challenges and low approval ratings, Sunak himself represents a relatively safe Conservative seat (Richmond, Yorkshire). In the 2019 general election, he won his seat with a significant majority (27,210 votes). Even if the Conservative Party performs poorly overall, it's highly unlikely that Sunak would lose his own seat. The probability of Sunak failing to be elected as an MP is very low, perhaps around 5-10%. Combining these probabilities: The question resolves as YES if either of these events occurs. To calculate the probability of at least one of these events occurring, we use the formula: P(A or B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A and B). Let's use the higher estimates for a more conservative approach: P(Ramaswamy nominee) = 0.02 P(Sunak not elected) = 0.10 P(Both occurring) ≈ 0.02 * 0.10 = 0.002 (assuming independence) P(At least one occurring) = 0.02 + 0.10 - 0.002 = 0.118 Therefore, the overall probability of this question resolving as YES is approximately 11.8%.

question.title: Will Biden remain President through end of July 2024?
question.body:
Resolves YES if Biden remains US President through the end of July 2024 (ET); resolves NO if he resigns, dies, or otherwise ceases to be President before then.

Temporary transfer of power under the 25th amendement (i.e. making his VP the Acting President) does not cause a YES resolution. (Acting President is different from President under the Constitution)

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Joe Biden remaining President through the end of July 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current health and age: Biden is currently 80 years old and will be 81 by July 2024. While he has maintained relatively good health, his advanced age does increase the risk of potential health issues. 2. Historical precedent: No U.S. President has died in office since John F. Kennedy in 1963, and no President has resigned since Richard Nixon in 1974. This suggests a generally low probability of a President not completing their term. 3. Political stability: There are currently no major political crises or scandals that would likely lead to Biden's resignation. 4. Biden's commitment to office: Biden has consistently expressed his intention to serve his full term and has even hinted at running for re-election in 2024. 5. Vice President preparedness: Kamala Harris is prepared to take over if necessary, which reduces the likelihood of Biden feeling pressured to resign due to inability to perform duties. 6. Time frame: The question asks about a period ending approximately 10 months from now, which is a relatively short time frame, reducing the probability of unforeseen events. 7. Medical advancements: Modern medical care significantly reduces the risk of sudden health issues becoming fatal, even for someone of Biden's age. 8. 25th Amendment clause: The question specifically states that temporary transfer of power under the 25th Amendment does not count as ceasing to be President, which eliminates one potential way Biden might briefly step aside. Considering all these factors, the probability of Biden remaining President through the end of July 2024 is quite high. While his age does present some increased health risks, the historical rarity of presidents not completing their terms, combined with Biden's current health and the short time frame in question, suggests a strong likelihood of him remaining in office.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed from a primary ballot for federal office under the 14th Amendment by July 15, 2024, and will Biden cease to be President before the end of July 2024?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if both of the following conditions are met:

1. As of July 15, 2024, Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment. The removal or block must be confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution. The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur after the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the condition is not met.

2. Joe Biden ceases to be US President before the end of July 2024 (ET) by resigning, dying, or otherwise leaving office. Temporary transfer of power under the 25th amendment (i.e., making his VP the Acting President) does not meet this condition, as Acting President is different from President under the Constitution.

The question resolves as "No" if either or both of these conditions are not met.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, we need to consider the likelihood of two separate events occurring, as both conditions must be met for the question to resolve as 'Yes.' 1. Donald Trump being removed from a primary ballot under the 14th Amendment by July 15, 2024: This is a contentious and complex legal issue. While there have been attempts to use the 14th Amendment to disqualify Trump from running for office, success has been limited. As of now, no state has successfully removed Trump from a ballot under these grounds. The Supreme Court is likely to weigh in on this issue, which could provide a definitive ruling. Given the legal complexities and the potential for appeals, it's unlikely but not impossible that Trump would be removed from a ballot by the specified date. 2. Joe Biden ceasing to be President before the end of July 2024: This condition requires Biden to leave office through resignation, death, or other means (excluding temporary transfer of power). Biden's health and age have been topics of discussion, but there's no concrete evidence suggesting he plans to resign or is in imminent health danger. The likelihood of this happening within the specified timeframe is quite low. For the question to resolve as 'Yes,' both of these low-probability events must occur. The probability of two independent events both occurring is the product of their individual probabilities, which makes the overall probability even lower. Given these factors, I would estimate the probability of both conditions being met as very low.

question.title: Will either Biden remain President through July 2024 or Trump be removed from a primary ballot under the 14th Amendment by July 15, 2024?
question.body: Will either of the following occur: (a) Biden remains US President through the end of July 2024, meaning he does not resign, die, or otherwise cease to be President before then (temporary transfer of power under the 25th amendment does not count as ceasing to be President); (b) Donald Trump is officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment as of July 15, 2024. The removal or block must be confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals after July 15, 2024.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, we need to consider both parts separately and then combine their probabilities. Part A: Biden remaining President through July 2024 Joe Biden is currently the President of the United States and is in generally good health for his age. While there are always risks associated with advanced age (Biden will be 81 in July 2024), the probability of a sitting president not completing their term due to death, resignation, or removal is historically low. Presidents typically serve out their full terms barring extraordinary circumstances. Given Biden's current status and the absence of any significant health concerns or political crises that might lead to resignation, the probability of him remaining President through July 2024 is very high, likely around 95%. Part B: Trump being removed from a primary ballot under the 14th Amendment by July 15, 2024 This is a more complex and uncertain situation. There have been discussions and some legal attempts to use Section 3 of the 14th Amendment to disqualify Trump from running for office due to his alleged role in the January 6th Capitol riot. However, as of now, no state has successfully removed Trump from the ballot on these grounds. There are several factors to consider: 1. Legal challenges are ongoing in multiple states. 2. The issue is highly contentious and likely to face significant legal and political opposition. 3. Even if a state were to attempt to remove Trump from the ballot, it would likely face immediate legal challenges and potential stays. 4. The Supreme Court has not yet ruled on this issue, and their decision could have a significant impact. Given these factors, while it's not impossible for Trump to be removed from a ballot under the 14th Amendment, the probability is relatively low. I would estimate it at around 20%. Combining the probabilities: The question asks if EITHER of these events will occur. To calculate this, we need to use the probability of neither event occurring and subtract it from 1. Probability of neither event = (1 - 0.95) * (1 - 0.20) = 0.05 * 0.80 = 0.04 Therefore, the probability of either event occurring is: 1 - 0.04 = 0.96 or 96%

question.title: Will the European Union announce new tariffs or duties on imports of Chinese electric vehicles before July 5, 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if, before July 5, 2024, credible sources report that the European Union (EU) has announced that new tariffs or duties will be imposed that would apply to imports of Chinese electric vehicles into the EU.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of this event occurring, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current trade tensions: There have been ongoing discussions and concerns within the EU about the influx of Chinese electric vehicles (EVs) into the European market. The EU has been worried about potential market distortions and unfair competition. 2. Recent investigations: In September 2023, the European Commission launched an anti-subsidy investigation into Chinese EVs, which is set to conclude by November 2024. This investigation could potentially lead to new tariffs or duties. 3. Timeframe: The question asks about an announcement before July 5, 2024, which is about 7 months from the time this question was created. This is a relatively short timeframe for completing an investigation and announcing new measures. 4. Political pressure: There is increasing pressure from European automakers and some EU member states to protect the domestic EV industry from Chinese competition. 5. Precedent: The EU has imposed tariffs on other Chinese products in the past when it believed there was unfair competition or subsidies involved. 6. Potential retaliation: The EU might be cautious about imposing new tariffs due to the risk of retaliation from China, which could harm other sectors of the EU economy. 7. Global economic conditions: The state of the global economy and any potential economic downturns could influence the EU's decision to impose new tariffs. 8. Climate goals: The EU's commitment to reducing carbon emissions might make it hesitant to impose tariffs that could slow the adoption of EVs. Considering these factors, I believe there is a moderate chance that the EU will announce new tariffs or duties on Chinese EVs before July 5, 2024. The ongoing investigation and political pressure suggest movement in this direction, but the relatively short timeframe and potential economic consequences may delay such an announcement.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (1) At least 5 named Dem House Members or US Senators pressure Biden to drop out before July 20th, 2024, AND (2) The EU does not announce new tariffs on Chinese EVs before July 5, 2024?
question.body:
(1) At least 5 named Democratic Party US House Members/US Senators must work together to ask Joe Biden to consider ending his 2024 re-election campaign, or urge him to do so, before Saturday, July 20th, 2024 (Pacific Time). This could be by signing a letter or another form of collective action. All five individuals must be part of the same group message. Five people separately telling reporters they think Biden should drop out is not sufficient. Reports of any number of unnamed democrats writing to Biden and asking him to step aside will not satisfy the criteria unless at least 5 qualifying names are made public before the end date. Ambiguous cases will err towards resolving NO. If these criteria are not met before July 20th, 2024, this condition resolves NO.

(2) The European Union (EU) must not announce any new tariffs or duties on imports of Chinese electric vehicles before July 5, 2024. This condition will resolve as YES if there are no credible reports of the EU announcing new tariffs or duties that would apply to imports of Chinese electric vehicles into the EU before the specified date.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of both events occurring, we need to analyze each part separately and then combine their likelihoods. 1. At least 5 named Dem House Members or US Senators pressuring Biden to drop out before July 20th, 2024: This scenario is highly unlikely for several reasons: a) Joe Biden is the incumbent president and the presumptive Democratic nominee. b) There's no strong alternative candidate within the Democratic Party. c) Publicly pressuring an incumbent president to drop out would be seen as extremely divisive and potentially damaging to the party. d) The requirement for a collective action (e.g., signing a letter) makes this even less likely, as it requires coordination and agreement among multiple officials. e) The deadline (July 20th, 2024) is relatively close to the election, making such a drastic move even more improbable. I would estimate the probability of this occurring at around 5% (0.05). 2. The EU not announcing new tariffs on Chinese EVs before July 5, 2024: This scenario is more likely to occur: a) While there have been discussions about potential tariffs on Chinese EVs in the EU, implementing such measures takes time and careful consideration. b) The EU generally prefers diplomatic solutions and negotiations before resorting to tariffs. c) The deadline (July 5th, 2024) is relatively soon, which doesn't leave much time for the EU to complete the necessary procedures for implementing new tariffs. d) However, there is growing concern in the EU about the competitiveness of Chinese EVs, which could potentially accelerate discussions on tariffs. I would estimate the probability of no new tariffs being announced before July 5th, 2024, at around 70% (0.7). To calculate the probability of both events occurring together, we multiply their individual probabilities: 0.05 * 0.7 = 0.035. This means there's approximately a 3.5% chance that both conditions will be met.

question.title: Will either of the following occur before their respective deadlines: (1) The EU announce new tariffs on Chinese EV imports, or (2) A group of 5 named Dem lawmakers pressure Biden to drop out?
question.body:
(1) The EU announces new tariffs or duties on imports of Chinese electric vehicles before July 5, 2024. This will resolve as **Yes** if credible sources report that the EU has announced that new tariffs or duties will be imposed that would apply to imports of Chinese electric vehicles into the EU.

(2) A group of at least 5 named Democratic Party US House Members or US Senators work together to ask Joe Biden to consider ending his 2024 re-election campaign, or to urge him to do so, before July 20th, 2024 (Pacific Time). This could be by signing a letter, speaking with Biden in person, or another form of collective action. All five individuals must be part of the same group message, and the names must be made public. In ambiguous cases where such names are reported but not confirmed beyond a reasonable doubt, this will resolve NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of this question resolving as YES, we need to consider both parts of the question separately and then combine their likelihoods. 1. EU announcing new tariffs on Chinese EV imports before July 5, 2024: The EU has been concerned about the influx of cheaper Chinese electric vehicles and their potential impact on the European auto industry. There have been discussions about implementing protective measures. However, the EU typically moves cautiously on such matters, considering potential trade repercussions and WTO rules. The deadline is relatively soon (about 7 weeks from now), which doesn't leave much time for the typically slow EU decision-making process. While it's possible, it's not highly likely in this short timeframe. 2. A group of 5 named Democratic lawmakers pressuring Biden to drop out before July 20, 2024: This scenario is less likely. Joe Biden is the incumbent president and the presumptive Democratic nominee for the 2024 election. While there have been concerns about his age and some polls showing low approval ratings, there hasn't been any significant movement within the Democratic Party to push him out. For five named lawmakers to publicly pressure him to drop out would be an extraordinary and potentially damaging move for the party. It's more likely that any such discussions would happen behind closed doors rather than in a public manner that meets the criteria specified. Combining these scenarios, we need only one to occur for the question to resolve as YES. The first scenario (EU tariffs) is more likely than the second (Dem lawmakers), but both are still relatively low probability events within the given timeframes. Given these considerations, I would estimate a low to moderate probability of either event occurring.

question.title: Will the New York Knicks win the 2024 NBA Finals?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if the New York Knicks are crowned the champion of the 2024 NBA Finals, according to [the NBA](https://www.nba.com/). It resolves as **No** for all other teams if they are eliminated from contention.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of the New York Knicks winning the 2024 NBA Finals, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current team performance: As of the 2022-2023 season, the Knicks finished 5th in the Eastern Conference with a 47-35 record. They made it to the second round of the playoffs but were eliminated by the Miami Heat. 2. Team composition: The Knicks have a solid core of players, including Julius Randle, Jalen Brunson, and RJ Barrett. They've also added Donte DiVincenzo in the offseason, which could improve their depth. 3. Eastern Conference competition: The Eastern Conference is highly competitive, with teams like the Milwaukee Bucks, Boston Celtics, and Miami Heat consistently performing well. The Knicks would need to overcome these teams to reach the Finals. 4. Western Conference powerhouses: Even if the Knicks make it out of the East, they would likely face tough competition from Western Conference teams like the Denver Nuggets (current champions), Golden State Warriors, or Phoenix Suns. 5. Historical performance: The Knicks haven't won an NBA championship since 1973, and they've only made the playoffs twice in the last ten years. This indicates a long-standing struggle to reach the highest level of success. 6. Coaching and management: Tom Thibodeau is a respected coach, but the team would need to make significant improvements to be considered true contenders. 7. Potential for trades or improvements: There's always a possibility of the team making significant moves before or during the 2023-2024 season, but as of now, no major changes have been announced. Given these factors, while the Knicks have shown improvement in recent years, they are not considered among the top favorites to win the 2024 NBA Finals. They would need to make substantial improvements and overcome several stronger teams to have a realistic chance at the championship.

question.title: Will the Miami Heat win and the New York Knicks not win the 2024 NBA Finals?
question.body:
This question resolves **Yes** if both of the following are true according to [the NBA](https://www.nba.com/): (a) The Miami Heat is crowned the champion of the 2024 NBA Finals. (b) The New York Knicks are not crowned the champion of the 2024 NBA Finals. 

It resolves **No** if either the Miami Heat is not crowned champion or the New York Knicks are crowned champion.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of this scenario, we need to consider several factors: 1. Miami Heat's performance: The Miami Heat reached the NBA Finals in 2023, losing to the Denver Nuggets. They have shown they can compete at a high level, with star players like Jimmy Butler and Bam Adebayo. However, they were the 8th seed in the Eastern Conference and had to fight through the play-in tournament, indicating some inconsistency during the regular season. 2. New York Knicks' performance: The Knicks have been improving in recent years but haven't reached the same level of success as the Heat. They made it to the second round of the playoffs in 2023 but were eliminated by the Miami Heat. 3. Competition in the NBA: There are several strong teams in the NBA that could prevent either team from winning the championship, such as the Denver Nuggets (defending champions), Boston Celtics, Milwaukee Bucks, and Golden State Warriors. 4. Historical context: Neither team has won an NBA championship recently. The Heat last won in 2013, while the Knicks haven't won since 1973. 5. Probability of specific outcomes: For this scenario to occur, we need the Heat to win AND the Knicks to not win. The probability of the Knicks not winning is quite high, but the probability of the Heat winning is lower. Considering these factors, it's more likely that neither team will win the 2024 NBA Finals than the specific scenario of the Heat winning and the Knicks not winning. The Heat have shown they can compete at a high level, but winning the championship is still a tall order given the strong competition in the NBA.

question.title: Will either the New York Knicks or the Miami Heat win the 2024 NBA Finals?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if either the New York Knicks or the Miami Heat is crowned the champion of the 2024 NBA Finals, according to [the NBA](https://www.nba.com/). It resolves as **No** if any other team is crowned champion or if both the New York Knicks and the Miami Heat are eliminated from contention.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of either the New York Knicks or the Miami Heat winning the 2024 NBA Finals, we need to consider several factors: Current team performance shows that both teams are competitive but not top-tier championship contenders. The Heat made it to the NBA Finals in 2023, demonstrating potential, while the Knicks have been improving but lack a deep playoff history. The Eastern Conference is highly competitive with strong teams like the Boston Celtics and Milwaukee Bucks, making their path to the Finals challenging. The Western Conference has traditionally been stronger, with teams like the Denver Nuggets and Golden State Warriors likely to contend for the championship. Roster changes could enhance their chances, but currently, neither team has a superstar player. The Heat's strong coaching under Erik Spoelstra gives them an edge over the Knicks. Overall, while the Heat have a better chance due to their recent success, both teams are considered underdogs against several other contenders, leading to a combined probability of 0.15 for either winning the Finals.

question.title: Will Liz Cheney be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Liz Cheney is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently listed; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Liz Cheney becoming the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current political landscape: Liz Cheney has positioned herself as a strong critic of former President Donald Trump, which has alienated her from a significant portion of the Republican base that still supports Trump. 2. Recent political history: Cheney lost her House leadership position and was censured by the Republican National Committee for her stance against Trump and her participation in the January 6th committee. 3. Primary challenge: Cheney lost her 2022 primary for Wyoming's at-large congressional district to a Trump-backed challenger, indicating a lack of support from her own state's Republican voters. 4. Fundraising and support: While Cheney has been able to raise significant funds, much of her support comes from anti-Trump Republicans and even some Democrats, which may not translate to broad Republican primary voter support. 5. Current polling: Cheney is not currently a frontrunner in any national polls for the 2024 Republican nomination. Other candidates like Trump, DeSantis, and Haley are polling much higher. 6. Time until the convention: There is still time until the 2024 Republican National Convention, but Cheney would need to overcome significant obstacles and dramatically shift Republican voter sentiment to become a viable candidate. 7. Republican party dynamics: The current Republican party still largely aligns with Trump's policies and rhetoric, which is at odds with Cheney's positions. 8. Potential for a third-party run: There has been speculation that Cheney might run as an independent or third-party candidate, which would further reduce her chances of becoming the Republican nominee. Given these factors, it appears highly unlikely that Liz Cheney will be selected as the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. While unexpected events could potentially shift the political landscape, the current evidence suggests that Cheney's chances are very low.

question.title: Will the Republican Party retain Ohio's 6th congressional district in the 2024 special election and Liz Cheney not be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if both of the following conditions are met:

1. Credible sources report that a person representing the Republican Party has won the special election for Ohio's 6th district, previously held by Bill Johnson. In case of disagreement among popular sources, an Ohio State source or statement will be used. If no election is held before January 1, 2025, this part of the question is annulled.

2. Liz Cheney is not selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. If any other candidate is selected, this condition is satisfied. This determination is based solely on the selection by the delegates of the Republican National Convention, regardless of who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
Let's break this down into the two conditions and analyze each:

1. Republican Party retaining Ohio's 6th congressional district in the 2024 special election:
Ohio's 6th district has been a Republican stronghold for many years. In the 2022 election, Republican Bill Johnson won with 67.9% of the vote. The district has consistently voted Republican in recent elections, and there's no indication of a significant shift in voter demographics or sentiment. Given this historical trend and the current political climate, it's highly likely that the Republican Party will retain this seat in a special election.

2. Liz Cheney not being the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election:
Liz Cheney has become a controversial figure within the Republican Party due to her opposition to former President Donald Trump and her role in the January 6th committee. She lost her 2022 primary in Wyoming by a large margin, indicating a lack of support from Republican voters. The current frontrunners for the 2024 Republican nomination are figures like Donald Trump, Ron DeSantis, and Nikki Haley, with Cheney not even being considered a serious contender. Given her current standing in the party and the lack of any indication that she plans to run, it's extremely unlikely that Liz Cheney would be selected as the Republican nominee.

Considering both conditions together, the probability of both occurring is very high. The Republican Party is very likely to retain Ohio's 6th district, and it's almost certain that Liz Cheney will not be the Republican presidential nominee. The only significant uncertainty comes from the possibility of an unexpected upset in the Ohio special election, but even that is a low probability event.

question.title: Will either of the following occur: (a) Liz Cheney becomes the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, or (b) The Republican Party retains Ohio's 6th congressional district in the 2024 special election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if either of the following occurs:

(a) Liz Cheney is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. This is determined solely by the decision of the delegates of the Republican National Convention, irrespective of who receives the nomination on the day of the election.

(b) A person representing the Republican Party wins the special election for Ohio's 6th congressional district. This will be confirmed by credible sources, and in case of disagreement among popular sources, an Ohio State source or statement will be used. If no election is held before January 1, 2025, this part of the question is annulled.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
Let's break this down into two parts and analyze each separately:

(a) Liz Cheney becoming the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election:
Liz Cheney has been a vocal critic of former President Donald Trump and voted to impeach him. This has made her unpopular among many Republican voters who still support Trump. She lost her House seat in Wyoming due to this stance. The Republican base currently seems to favor candidates who align with Trump's policies and rhetoric. Given these factors, it's highly unlikely that Cheney would be selected as the Republican nominee. The probability of this happening is extremely low.

(b) The Republican Party retaining Ohio's 6th congressional district in the 2024 special election:
Ohio's 6th congressional district has been a Republican stronghold for many years. In the 2022 election, Republican Bill Johnson won with 67.4% of the vote. The district has a Cook Partisan Voting Index of R+16, indicating a strong Republican lean. While special elections can sometimes produce surprising results, the historical voting patterns and the strong Republican lean of this district make it highly likely that the Republicans will retain this seat. The probability of this happening is very high.

Considering that only one of these events needs to occur for the question to resolve as Yes, and given that the second event (b) is highly probable, the overall probability of this question resolving as Yes is very high.

question.title: Will Greece qualify for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if Greece participates in a Semi-final and is officially announced by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) as having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final. If Greece does not qualify, the question will resolve as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Greece qualifying for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. Historical performance: Greece has a strong track record in Eurovision. Since the introduction of semi-finals in 2004, Greece has qualified for the Grand Final in 16 out of 19 attempts. This gives them an 84% success rate in qualifying. 2. Recent performance: In the last five years (2019-2023), Greece has qualified for the Grand Final four times, missing out only in 2019. This shows a consistent recent performance. 3. Quality of entries: Greece often sends competitive entries that appeal to both juries and televotes. While we don't know the 2024 entry yet, their track record suggests they're likely to send a strong contender. 4. Voting patterns: Greece often benefits from diaspora voting and has strong alliances with countries like Cyprus, which can help in the semi-final stage. 5. Semi-final allocation: The semi-final in which Greece is placed can affect their chances, but this information is not available yet. However, their consistent performance suggests they can qualify from either semi-final. 6. Competition level: The overall quality of entries in their semi-final will impact Greece's chances, but this is unknown at this point. 7. Changes in format or voting: Any potential changes to the Eurovision format or voting system could impact Greece's chances, but no major changes have been announced for 2024. Given Greece's strong historical performance, consistent recent qualifications, and generally competitive entries, there is a high likelihood of them qualifying for the Grand Final in 2024. However, Eurovision results can be unpredictable, and there's always a chance of an upset or an unexpectedly weak entry. Considering all these factors, I would estimate a high probability of Greece qualifying for the Grand Final in 2024.

question.title: Will Lithuania qualify and Greece fail to qualify for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if both of the following occur: (a) Lithuania participates in a Semi-final and is officially announced by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) as having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final, and (b) Greece does not qualify for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final. If either Lithuania does not qualify or Greece qualifies, the question will resolve as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of this outcome, we need to consider several factors: 1. Historical performance: Lithuania has qualified for the Grand Final in 8 out of 21 attempts since the introduction of semi-finals in 2004. Greece has a strong track record, qualifying for the Grand Final in 16 out of 18 attempts since 2004. 2. Recent performance: Lithuania qualified for the Grand Final in 2021, 2022, and 2023, showing an upward trend. Greece qualified in 2021 and 2022 but failed to qualify in 2023, breaking their streak. 3. Eurovision voting patterns: Lithuania often receives support from other Baltic countries and the diaspora vote. Greece traditionally receives strong support from Cyprus and other neighboring countries. 4. Quality of entries: As of now, we don't know the specific songs or artists for 2024, which adds uncertainty. Both countries have had varying quality of entries in recent years. 5. Semi-final allocation: The distribution of countries in each semi-final can significantly affect qualification chances. This information is not available yet for 2024. 6. Changing trends: Eurovision voting patterns and preferences can shift from year to year. Greece's failure to qualify in 2023 might indicate a potential decline in their consistent performance. 7. Probability of both events occurring: For this question to resolve as Yes, we need both Lithuania to qualify AND Greece to fail. This combination of events is less likely than either event occurring independently. Given these factors, Lithuania's recent success suggests they have a decent chance of qualifying, perhaps around 60%. Greece's strong overall record but recent stumble might put their qualification chances at about 70%. For both events to occur as specified (Lithuania qualifying and Greece not qualifying), we need to multiply the probabilities: 0.60 * 0.30 = 0.18. While there's a lot of uncertainty, especially without knowing the 2024 entries or semi-final allocations, based on recent trends and historical performance, I estimate a relatively low probability for this specific combination of outcomes.

question.title: Will either Greece or Lithuania qualify for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if either of the following occurs: (a) Greece participates in a Semi-final and is officially announced by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) as having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final. (b) Lithuania participates in a Semi-final and is officially announced by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) as having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final. If neither Greece nor Lithuania qualify, the question will resolve as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of either Greece or Lithuania qualifying for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. Historical performance: Both Greece and Lithuania have had mixed results in recent years. Greece has qualified for the final 16 out of 19 times since the introduction of semi-finals in 2004, but failed to qualify in 2016, 2018, and 2019. Lithuania has qualified 11 out of 20 times since 2004, including in the last four consecutive contests (2019, 2021, 2022, 2023). 2. Recent trends: Both countries have shown improvement in recent years. Greece qualified for the final in 2021, 2022, and 2023, indicating a return to form. Lithuania's recent streak of qualifications suggests they've found a winning formula. 3. Quality of entries: While we don't know the specific songs for 2024 yet, both countries have been sending competitive entries in recent years. 4. Voting patterns: Both countries benefit from diaspora voting and regional support, which can help in the semi-finals. 5. Semi-final allocation: The distribution of countries in each semi-final can affect qualification chances, but this is unknown at this time. 6. Combined chances: With two countries in question, the probability of at least one qualifying is higher than for a single country. Given these factors, the chances of at least one of these countries qualifying seem quite high. Greece has a strong track record overall, and both countries have been performing well recently. The fact that we have two chances (one for each country) significantly increases the likelihood of a positive outcome. However, Eurovision results can be unpredictable, and factors such as the quality of other countries' entries and the specific songs chosen by Greece and Lithuania for 2024 could influence the outcome. Considering all these aspects, I would estimate a high probability of at least one of these countries qualifying.

question.title: Will Trump's lead over Biden be greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average?
question.body:
This question will resolve as Donald Trump's lead over Joe Biden in 538's [national polling average for the 2024 presidential election](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/2024/national/) as reported on the chart for the date of July 15, 2024, when accessed by Metaculus on July 17, 2024.

For the purposes of this question, a positive value means a Trump lead, while a negative value means Biden is leading. For example, as of July 5, 2024, the value reported for July 5 is Trump 2.4 points ahead of Biden, which would be a positive value of 2.4 for this purposes of this question.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Trump's lead over Biden being greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current polling trends: As of July 5, 2024, Trump is reported to be 2.4 points ahead of Biden. This falls within the range we're looking at for July 15. 2. Time frame: We're looking at a prediction for about 10 days in the future from the last reported data point. In such a short time frame, significant changes in polling averages are less likely unless major events occur. 3. Historical volatility: Presidential polling averages tend to fluctuate, but usually within a relatively narrow range, especially this close to an election. 4. Potential events: Any major events (debates, scandals, economic news) occurring between July 5 and July 15 could shift the numbers, but we have no specific information about such events. 5. Margin of error: Polls typically have a margin of error, which means small fluctuations are common and expected. 6. Regression to the mean: If the current 2.4 point lead is seen as somewhat of an outlier, there might be a slight tendency for the numbers to move closer to previous averages. 7. Timing relative to the election: July 15 is relatively close to the election, which means voter preferences are likely becoming more solidified, reducing the likelihood of major swings. Given these factors, it seems reasonably likely that Trump's lead will remain within the specified range. The current 2.4 point lead is already within this range, and barring any major events, it's plausible that it will stay there. However, there's also a significant chance it could fall below 2 or rise above 3, given normal polling fluctuations and potential events.

question.title: Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President AND will Trump's lead over Biden be less than or equal to 2 or greater than 3 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if both of the following conditions are met:

1. Prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement that he will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle. The statement must be unambiguous and conclusive, leaving no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination.

2. On July 15, 2024, Donald Trump's lead over Joe Biden in 538's national polling average for the 2024 presidential election is less than or equal to 2 points or greater than 3 points, as reported on the chart for that date and accessed by Metaculus on July 17, 2024. A positive value indicates a Trump lead, while a negative value indicates a Biden lead.

If both conditions are not met, this question will resolve as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of this compound question, we need to consider both conditions separately and then combine them. 1. Biden announcing he won't accept the Democratic nomination: This is highly unlikely. As of now, Biden is the incumbent president and the presumptive Democratic nominee for 2024. He has consistently stated his intention to run for re-election. While there have been concerns about his age and some calls for him to step aside, he and his team have remained firm in their commitment to his candidacy. It would be unprecedented for a sitting president to suddenly withdraw so close to the election. The probability of this happening is very low, perhaps around 5%. 2. Trump's lead over Biden in 538's national polling average: This condition is more likely to be met. Current polling shows a close race between Biden and Trump, with leads often within the margin of error. The specific condition (lead ≤2 or >3) covers a large range of possible outcomes, making it more likely to occur. However, polls can fluctuate, and we're projecting several months into the future. Based on current trends and historical data, the probability of Trump's lead falling into one of these ranges on the specific date is moderately high, perhaps around 70%. For the overall question to resolve as YES, both conditions must be met. In probability terms, we need to multiply these probabilities: 0.05 (Biden withdrawing) * 0.70 (Trump's lead in the specified range) = 0.035 or 3.5%. This calculation assumes the events are independent, which is a reasonable assumption given that Biden's decision to withdraw would likely be based on factors other than his exact polling numbers on a specific future date. Given the extremely low likelihood of Biden withdrawing, even the more probable polling condition cannot significantly raise the overall probability.

question.title: Will either Trump's lead over Biden be greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average, or will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if either of the following occurs:

1. Donald Trump's lead over Joe Biden is greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3 in 538's [national polling average for the 2024 presidential election](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/2024/national/) as reported on the chart for the date of July 15, 2024, when accessed by Metaculus on July 17, 2024. For the purposes of this question, a positive value means a Trump lead, while a negative value means Biden is leading.

2. Prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle. The statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle.

If neither of these conditions is met, this question will resolve as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, we need to consider both conditions separately and then combine their probabilities. 1. Trump's lead over Biden being greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3 on July 15, 2024: As of now (July 2023), it's difficult to predict with high accuracy what the polling numbers will be exactly a year from now. However, recent polls have shown a close race between Trump and Biden, with neither consistently holding a large lead. A lead of 2-3 points for Trump is within the realm of possibility, but it's a relatively narrow range. Given the volatility of polls and the long time frame, I'd estimate the probability of this specific condition being met at around 15-20%. 2. Joe Biden announcing he won't accept the Democratic nomination before July 15, 2024: This scenario is less likely. Biden has consistently expressed his intention to run for re-election and has already launched his 2024 campaign. While there have been concerns about his age and some calls for him to step aside, he and his team have remained firm in their commitment to run. For Biden to reverse course and decline the nomination would be a major political shock. It's not impossible, especially if there were a significant health issue or major political scandal, but it's quite unlikely. I'd estimate the probability of this happening at around 5-10%. Combining these probabilities: The question resolves as YES if either of these events occurs. Using the rule of probability for independent events (P(A or B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A and B)), and using the higher end of our estimates for a more conservative approach: P(YES) = P(Trump lead 2-3) + P(Biden declines) - P(Both occur) ≈ 0.20 + 0.10 - (0.20 * 0.10) ≈ 0.30 - 0.02 ≈ 0.28 Therefore, I estimate the probability of this question resolving as YES to be approximately 28%.

question.title: Will 538 Project Biden as the favorite on Friday?
question.body:
This market will resolve to “Yes” if Joe Biden has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Donald Trump according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024. This market will resolve to “No” if Donald Trump has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Joe Biden according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024. If Biden and Trump have equal odds, this market will resolve 50-50.

The resolution source will be FiveThirtyEight's 2024 presidential election forecast, https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2024-election-forecast/, specifically the numbers indicated by the blue and red trend lines for this market's resolution date. Changes in the methodology by which FiveThirtyEight calculates its figures will have no bearing on the resolution of this market.

This market will resolve according to the datapoints for July 19 as soon as datapoints for July 20 become available. This market may not resolve until the July 20 datapoints are available. If no datapoints for July 19 are available by July 22, 11:59 PM ET, this market will resolve according to the nearest previous figures to July 19.

Please note the resolution refers to the odds of each candidate winning as a number out of 100 reported to the 1 digit mark (eg. "Trump 57 times out of 100"). The listed number of simulations out of 1,000 won by each candidate will NOT be considered.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current polling and forecasts: As of now (July 2023), Biden and Trump are the presumptive nominees for their respective parties, but the election is still over a year away. Current polls show a close race, with some giving Biden a slight edge and others favoring Trump. 2. FiveThirtyEight's methodology: FiveThirtyEight is known for its data-driven approach and tends to be more conservative in its predictions, especially this far out from the election. 3. Historical precedent: Incumbent presidents often have an advantage in re-election bids, but this can be affected by factors like approval ratings and economic conditions. 4. Potential events: A lot can happen between now and July 2024 that could significantly impact the race, including economic changes, foreign policy events, or unforeseen scandals. 5. Biden's age and performance: Concerns about Biden's age and mental acuity could affect his standing, especially if these concerns grow over the next year. 6. Trump's legal issues: The ongoing legal challenges facing Trump could potentially impact his candidacy or public perception. 7. Third-party candidates: While not mentioned in the question, the presence of strong third-party candidates could affect the probabilities for both main candidates. Given these factors, I believe it's more likely than not that Biden will be the favorite in FiveThirtyEight's forecast on July 19, 2024. The incumbent advantage, combined with Trump's legal issues, may give Biden a slight edge. However, the race is likely to be close, and there's a significant chance that Trump could be leading at that point.

question.title: Will Kamala Harris’ VP Pick be Kelly or Shapiro and will 538 Project Trump as the favorite on Friday?
question.body:
This market resolves YES if BOTH of the following occur: (a) Kamala Harris announces her pick for running mate being either Mark Kelly or Josh Shapiro before August 7th, confirmed by Kamala herself, and (b) Donald Trump has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Joe Biden according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024. 

The market resolves NO if either: (a) Kamala Harris announces anyone else as her running mate, or (b) Joe Biden has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Donald Trump according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024.

For Kamala Harris' VP pick, the resolution source is Kamala Harris' announcement. For the FiveThirtyEight projection, the resolution source is FiveThirtyEight's 2024 presidential election forecast, specifically the numbers indicated by the blue and red trend lines for July 19, 2024.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To resolve YES, this question requires two separate conditions to be met, which makes it less likely overall. Let's break down each condition: 1. Kamala Harris' VP pick: - The timeframe is relatively short (before August 7th, 2024). - Only two specific candidates are mentioned: Mark Kelly and Josh Shapiro. - While both are prominent Democrats, there's no strong indication that either is a frontrunner for the VP position. - There are many other potential candidates that Harris could choose from. 2. FiveThirtyEight projection on July 19, 2024: - This is over a year away, making it difficult to predict with certainty. - Current polls and projections can change significantly over time. - Historically, incumbents often have an advantage, which could favor Biden. - However, various factors like economic conditions, international events, and campaign performance can influence projections. Considering these factors: - The VP pick condition is quite specific and restrictive, lowering the probability significantly. - The FiveThirtyEight projection is more of a toss-up, but slightly favoring Biden as the incumbent. The combination of these two conditions makes a YES resolution quite unlikely. The VP pick alone is a low probability event, and it needs to be coupled with a specific polling outcome over a year from now.

question.title: Will Poland qualify for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if Poland participates in a Semi-final and is officially announced by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) as having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final. If Poland does not qualify, the question will resolve as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Poland qualifying for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. Historical performance: Poland has qualified for the Grand Final in 8 out of 17 attempts since the introduction of semi-finals in 2004. This gives them a qualification rate of about 47%. 2. Recent performance: In the last five years (2019-2023), Poland qualified for the Grand Final three times (2019, 2021, and 2022), missing out in 2023 and 2020 (2020 was cancelled due to COVID-19). This recent record shows a slight improvement over their overall average. 3. Quality of entry: As of now (April 2024), we don't know what Poland's entry for Eurovision 2024 will be. The quality of the song and performer will significantly impact their chances of qualification. 4. Competition: The level of competition in Poland's semi-final will also affect their chances. We don't know yet which semi-final they'll be in or who their competitors will be. 5. Voting patterns: Poland often benefits from diaspora voting, particularly from countries like the UK and Ireland, which can help their chances if these countries are in the same semi-final. 6. Staging and performance: Poland has had mixed results with staging in recent years. A strong stage performance can significantly boost their chances. 7. Changes in the voting system: Any changes to the voting system for 2024 could impact Poland's chances, but as of now, we don't have information about significant changes. Given these factors, Poland's chances of qualification seem slightly better than a coin flip. Their recent performance has been relatively strong, and they have shown the ability to create entries that resonate with both juries and televoters. However, without knowing the specific details of their 2024 entry or the competition they'll face, it's difficult to be highly confident in either direction.

question.title: At the Paris Summer Olympics in 2024, will the men's 100m dash winning time break the Olympic record of 9.63s?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if any athlete runs the Men's 100M race at the 2024 Paris Summer Olympics in less than 9.63s, according to results posted by the [International Olympic Committee](https://olympics.com/en/olympic-games/olympic-results) or credible sources. If this does not happen, this question resolves as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of breaking the Olympic record of 9.63s in the men's 100m dash at the 2024 Paris Olympics, we need to consider several factors: 1. Olympic record: The current Olympic record of 9.63s was also set by Usain Bolt in 2012. It has stood for over a decade, which indicates its difficulty to break. 3. Recent performances: In recent years, no athlete has consistently run times close to 9.63s. The fastest time in 2023 was 9.83s by Noah Lyles. 4. Talent pool: While there are several talented sprinters, none have shown the consistent ability to threaten Bolt's times. 5. Technological advancements: Improvements in track surfaces, starting blocks, and shoe technology could potentially aid faster times. 6. Environmental factors: Favorable weather conditions in Paris could potentially assist in faster times. 7. Rarity of sub-9.70 times: Since Bolt's retirement, sub-9.70 times have become extremely rare, with only a handful of athletes achieving this. 8. Pressure of the Olympics: The high-pressure environment of the Olympics can sometimes lead to extraordinary performances. Given these factors, while it's possible for the record to be broken, it seems unlikely. The gap between current top performances and the Olympic record is significant. Most of the world's top sprinters are running in the 9.80s to 9.90s range, which is still quite far from 9.63s. However, we can't completely rule out the possibility of an exceptional performance or the emergence of a new talent. The Olympics often bring out the best in athletes, and records are meant to be broken.
